[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Sorry, I'm a little confused.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Your name and address for the record.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Yes, Barbara Burke 37 Hicks Avenue Medford.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Good evening, Superintendent, Chair and Mayor, thank you for giving us this opportunity to speak this evening.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I'm speaking on behalf of the teachers, the families, and the students of Medford, I actually grew up in Medford.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I'm a former graduate of Medford High School, and currently I'm a first grade teacher with over 24 years of service to our city.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And they'll always be a budget to balance.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Above all, it takes knowledge and good judgment, the original proposed budget, if it's passed.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: that proposes these cuts to our school department, especially the Miss Tech school will affect us in the following ways.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We'll have bigger class sizes that will affect our social and emotional needs of our most needy children.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Since the pandemic method made it a priority to support all students with enough educators and programs in the schools to address their needs.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: These cuts will not allow for these programs and teachers to continue to provide this support, the message tech school will be impacted the most by these cuts which also includes the therapeutic learning program as well as the newcomers.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We can all agree that the early elementary years are very important years that as we are building these necessary foundational skills for learning in life.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Research shows that having large class sizes impacts the students in many ways, including less individualized support for students overpopulated classrooms can cause more anxiety and children, and is a challenge to provide consistent communication with families.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Please put yourself in these little shoes of our youngest population and make a decision to put them first when making important decisions with our school budget.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We reached out to a lot of different entities over the course of Thursday afternoon when we got the original ruling, and Friday evening when they did their second re-look at the rules.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And, you know, rules are great, but sometimes they don't fit.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Everybody doesn't fit into that box.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And that's when you expect a board of their caliber to make those kinds of decisions.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: that everyone can live with and not an unfair, unjust decision.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And what they did is they just corroborated, collaborated together.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's not the first time.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It probably won't be the last time.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We fought for you kids.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I want you to know that.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We weren't giving up.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We put everything behind and we said we're just pushing ahead and we're going to the courts because if MIA can't make the right decision, we're going to go to an unbiased individual to do it.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: That's what we did.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank goodness there was a judge that stayed around past closing time on Friday.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I want to thank the clerk of courts.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And the clerks that stayed there as well as the judge that stayed there.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We also have one, express its sincere condolences to the family of Gene Richard Citrano, Sr.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mr. Citrano was the father of Andrew's math teacher, Gene Richard Citrano, Jr.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Could we all please rise for a moment of silence on the passing of these individuals?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mr. Russo.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Make motions now.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Normally, new business would be on the agenda.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And then the motion would be sent somewhere so that everyone has an opportunity to know what the topic is.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: OK.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Can we suspend the rules so that we can hear our colleagues' motions?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Open meeting law to me, it's open meeting law.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: If you want to object to my ruling, feel free.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's an open meeting law.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Generally, you have things on the agenda written clearly so the public knows what you're going to talk about.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So if they want to be here to talk about it, they have ample opportunity to.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: That's the purpose of open meeting law.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: That's all.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: You just have to put it on.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Well, you could write it that way.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: You could make your motion in that form that I'd like to offer this topic be sent to the subcommittee on rules or whatever it is.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So you could put it in there so it's clear that that's your purpose.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Or it could go to subcommittee right out.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Subcommittee can have a meeting on any topic and they post the meeting, the topic, and then people can come to that.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Right.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It can go there, start there, and the work could be done there, and then it comes to the floor.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Either way.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: OK.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: There's a motion to adjourn.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I can state that there was no change.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We're talking about soccer.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: What are we talking about?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Ms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mostone.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Perfectly said.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Ms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Van der Kloot.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And at this time, I'd like to thank you for all the work you put in, because getting the GVL back off the ground was not an easy task.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And with you and the other communities, we've sat at the table many, many times over the course of the summer to make sure this was in place and working.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: and that we're representative, and really to make those other communities that voted us out feel a little bad about this.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So hopefully someday we'll go back and play them and show them what we're all about.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: But a lot of hard work, so thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So motion to approve this report?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Place it on file.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: On the motion by Mr. Russo, seconded by Ms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: VanDekloot.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: All those opposed?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And as soon as we hear back.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Hi, John.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So Aleesha Nunley is in the process of closing the books for the municipality.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And once they're closed, they get submitted to DOR.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: and then they certify the free cash from the prior year.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we're in like a hold pattern right now.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Hopefully October we'll get notification of our free cash allotment and that's when we can submit papers to the council from free cash.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Okay.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Probably not.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Once free cash is certified, we'll probably accumulate a few projects and put them forth.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Like the playgrounds, we're waiting for the CPC committee to make its motions of approval.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And that goes to city council as well.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Free cash?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I believe, is it October?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They're waiting for the final applications next week?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: To the extent we're able to get it through CPC, it's less bonding for the community.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So it's coming out of the pockets of monies that we've already collected.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's an allocation.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It really is.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: When you look at a whole spreadsheet, it's coming from different pockets.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Of course there will be a plan B if we don't get the money.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: But we are not going to jump to plan B before we hear on plan A. And if they move sooner than later, we can get this in the pipeline.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And I believe the Roberts took them about a week to do.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So it could be over a school vacation week as well.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Once we get approval, we can move.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mr. Lorenzo was the father of students at the Columbus Elementary School and the nephew of school committee member Aaron DiBenedetto.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Okay, the other, we have two resolutions.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Be it resolved that the Medford School Committee express its sincere condolences to the family of Salvatore Caraviello.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mr. Caraviello was the uncle of Medford City Councilor Richard Caraviello.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Also be it resolved that the Medford School Committee express its sincere condolences to the family of Elizabeth Irving.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Ms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Irving was the mother of McGlynn Middle School math teacher Robin Irving.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: She passed away June 22 at the age of 93 years old.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: A lifelong resident of West Medford, she was the mother of six girls who all graduated from Medford High School.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Robin Irving, the father of Robin, passed away January 4, 2016 at the age of 88 years old.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Could we please all rise for a moment of silence on the passing of... Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Also, we have a long resolution.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: To hold harmless 2019 10th grade MCAS due to racist question.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Whereas, the graduation requirement makes the 10th grade MCAS exam one of the highest stakes exams most Massachusetts students take.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Whereas, teachers, families, schools, and tax payers all invest time and resources to give students the best possible chance at success on the exam.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Whereas, the recent 10th grade MCAS English exam contained an essay that required students to write a journal entry from the perspective of an openly racist character.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And whereas, the Mass Deci

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: was unable to defend the question, quickly moving to not have it count.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And whereas we only discovered this because students had the courage to violate the rules about discussing specific MCAS questions.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And whereas research shows that exposure to negative stereotypes can have a negative impact on student performance.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And whereas the impact of the racist question on performance cannot be quantified.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Now, therefore, be it resolved that the Medford School Committee calls on DESE to exempt students who took the test with the rejected question from the graduation exam requirement, and further that the Medford School Committee calls for DESE to immediately implement a policy of releasing old MCAS questions so that there can be transparency to prevent such egregious errors in the future, and further resolved that a copy of this resolution be delivered to DESE, the governor, and the Medford state and local legislative delegations, and otherwise widely distributed.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mr. Russo, on the motion?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Motion to approve.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Is there a second on the floor?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Seconded by Mr. Ruggiero.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Roll call vote, please.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Senator Stone?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Yes.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And a vote of 5 in the affirmative, 2 absent, and the motion passes.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So thank you to the teachers that are still in the audience here.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Item two, report on the science of dyslexia.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Dr. Nadine Gabb.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Gabb, I'm sorry.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Good evening.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: While that's being set up, I would like to read a biography on Dr. Gabb.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Dr. Gabb is an associate professor of pediatrics at Boston Children's Hospital and the Harvard Medical School.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: She received her PhD in psychology from the University of Zurich in Switzerland and did post-doctoral training at Stanford University and MIT.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Her research with the laboratories of cognitive neuroscience focuses on the development of typical and atypical language and literary skills, as well as pre-markers of learning disabilities.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: More specifically, she works on the identification of possible pre-markers of reading disabilities, including developmental dyslexia.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: In the pre-reading and infant brain, the identification of the underlying neural mechanism of comorbidity of developmental dyslexia and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: and the development of tablet-based technology for early screening approaches for learning disabilities.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Her lab works closely with over 50 private and public schools nationwide, and she's a frequent speaker in the community.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: She's the 2019 recipient of the LDA Award, Learning Disabilities Association of America Award, and in 2018, Dr. Gabb was presented with the Alan C. Crocker Award for her advocacy on behalf of children with dyslexia and reading disabilities and efforts around the recent passage

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: of the Massachusetts Screening Legislation.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: She has also been recognized by the International Dyslexia Association in receipt of the Alice H. Garside Award for Outstanding Leadership in Advancing the Science and Advocacy of Dyslexia.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: She is further a recipient of the T. Barry Brazelton Award for Innovation at Boston's Children's Hospital.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: She's a scientific advisory board member of the Dyslexia Foundation and Landmark School and a founder of the New England Research on Dyslexia Society.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Welcome, Dr. Gobb.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mr. Ruggiero.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: There's a motion on the floor, seconded by Ms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Anne DeClune and Mr. Sciarro.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So thank you all for joining us.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Father Casey, elected officials, all of the officers here today, as well as the citizens.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: This is a historic day, a day that has been long in the coming.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Welcome to the groundbreaking of the Medford Police Headquarters.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: This headquarters represents a new era in policing in Medford.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: This station is critical to 21st century policing model that our offices embody.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It took perseverance by many to make this happen.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Many with us today, so thank you all.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: This new facility will improve readiness and morale and will compliment the dedication the members of the Medford Police Department demonstrate daily.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It will permit these committed men and women to come to work in a building that they are proud of each and every day.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: This groundbreaking ceremony is an exciting first step in the legacy of the Medford Police Department and our service to the residents of Medford.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The state-of-the-art facility will be a beacon of safety for our community for years to come.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So thank you, thank you, thank you, all of you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So you have made this a better project.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So thank you, Paul and the team in the building department.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Her office has been at the meetings regularly and has made sure that this building is built to our 21st century standards from an energy perspective, environmental perspective.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And I think you can see the pile behind us.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We had to let that wait for about six, seven months because we're building up the site.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Because in 50 years, we don't know where the Mystic River is going to end up.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And we wanted to protect our investment.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we spent the time in order to make this site be about four feet, four feet, am I correct?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Four feet taller, higher.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: four feet higher.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So thank you Alicia Hunt for all the work you've done and also Shab Khan from our procurement office.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Shab has made sure everything has been ticked and tied and done correctly so according to the law.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So thank you Shab from our team.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We of course have the members of the Medford Police Department that went and visited many sites

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They saw some new stations, some not so new stations.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They tried to pick the best of what they saw.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And I think that when we open up this building, you're going to see that this is a beautiful building.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's an efficient building, and it will work for the benefit of the men and women of our Medford Police Department.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And a man that I'm going to introduce up next, Jeff Shaw.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Jeff Shaw has been with us for the last seven years.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I know he's going to elaborate in his words, but he's been with us since we started doing the space needs assessment.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And Jeff has been a partner.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And if I told you he's looked at 10 sites for us, that's probably an understatement.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Whenever I had an idea, or if I drove by a vacant lot, or I drove by a building, I'd say, hey, Jeff, what do you think?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Can you go, can you fit a police station on that, number one?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And what would it look like?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: in the surroundings.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And Jeff has done more than one big sketch for us to see if we could find a perfect location.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And it wasn't until an officer that I won't name came by and visited my office and he said, have you looked at the training center?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And I'm like, you guys use the training center.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And he was like, that'd be a perfect location, because we like being right here.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We like this location.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We like the proximity.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We like being in the square.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So to that officer, thank you for opening up our eyes, because we really, we were not looking at this at that time.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And today would not have been possible without our DPW crew that put together everything that you see here in the last minute, as well as the Murphy brothers that provided the tenting for us.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So, you know, thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It takes a village, and you guys are part of our village, and we really appreciate all the work you do.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And sometimes you're in the background, but we know you're there, and you're always trying to look out for our best interest.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So thank you to our whole DPW department for everything you do every day.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: You know, Marion mentioned, D.A.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Ryan mentioned, that you call 911 and people come.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we have our police that come, we have our fire that come, and a lot of times we have our DPW that come.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So they're an integral role in public safety in our community.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Second.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Item number two, report on upcoming MBTA road closures.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We have Mr. Terry McCarthy with us of the team, who has been the main point person for the GLX project in the city of Medford.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: You notice he's wearing green.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: He's a reason.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And I'm not the president of the team.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: If I could, the chief has been extremely involved in this process.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I think pretty much weekly at this point they've been meeting with Todd Blake and Tim McGibbon, our engineer.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: A lot of the streets that might be cut through now will have postings on them, and there will be officers at the other end enforcing it.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So a lot of the streets to the right of Main Street, I guess, if you were going to Somerville, a lot of them will be limited to just neighborhood traffic, so not cut-through traffic.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And then the schools, I know we moved a bus stop up a little farther up, a new crosswalk we put in.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we can get a message out to the schools, but certainly the police are well informed.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Item 7, report on UDL Emergency Preparedness Committee Kathleen Madaglio and Melanie McLaughlin.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Is there a motion on the floor to accept this report, place it on file?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: All those in favor?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: All those opposed?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Motion passes.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Okay, new business.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: School committee resolutions.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Be it resolved that the Medford School Committee express its sincere condolences to the family of William Bill Brady.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mr. Brady was a member of the Medford School Committee for 25 years.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: He was a tireless advocate for all aspects of education, and he will be missed in Medford.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mr. Brady was the uncle of Medford math coach Ellie O'Leary.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Be it resolved that the Medford School Committee express its sincere condolences to the family of Elaine Torres.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Ms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Torres was the wife of the late Angel Torres, who was a teacher and coach at Medford High School.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Be it resolved that the Medford School Committee express its sincere condolences to the family of Patrick Carr.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mr. Carr was a Medford police detective for many years, and he was the husband of the late Shirley Carr, an administrative assistant at the Medford Vocational Technical High School.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Be it resolved that the Medford School Committee express its sincere condolences to the family of Guadalupe Maturana.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mrs. Maturana was the wife of the late Guy Maturana, who established the Spartans Youth Football League, which eventually became the Pop Warner Football, as well served as president of the North Medford Little League.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: both of which he guided voluntarily for years.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Two of her sons, Craig and James, are in the Mustang Hall of Fame, and her son Alan is a member of the Medford Rotary Club.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Also, Adam is a member of our licensing commission.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Be it resolved that the Medford School Committee express its sincere condolences to the family of James Hayden Downs, father of Andrew's middle school principal, Michael Downs.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mr. Downs was a retired Vietnam veteran residing in Nashville, Tennessee.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: If we could all please rise for a moment of silence.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: School Committee Resolution.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Whereas, free public schools available to all students without exception are foundational to our democracy and are required by the state constitution.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And whereas, all of our students, no matter where they live, deserve high-quality public schools that teach the whole child and provide them with a rich school experience that addresses their academic, social, and emotional needs.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Whereas, the state's foundation budget formula, which determines state aid to each district, has been woefully out of date for years, thereby underfunding our districts by more than $1 billion a year for essential educational services.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And whereas, an updated foundation budget formula would bring Medford up to $4,134,000

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: $775 in additional state aid each year, allowing us to move closer to providing all students with the education to which they are entitled as residents of the Commonwealth.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And whereas the legislature failed to pass any foundation budget legislation in the last session, leaving districts, educators, and students without the funds necessary to support the schools our students deserve in every district in the state.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Therefore, be it resolved that the Medford School Committee urges the legislature

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: to approve and fully fund a new foundation budget formula and support the Education Promise Act as submitted by Senator Sonia Chang-Diaz on May 1, 2019.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And if I could add, the Senate docket number is 101.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It had not received a number, a bill number, but that is certainly a way to track it until it receives such.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I also want to just make note a couple of weeks ago I announced here that we were going to be fighting the fight and even at the Martin Luther King breakfast for the NAACP we stressed that really it's something we all have to be advocating for because certainly the districts across the commonwealth are being underfunded in general and then when you look at Medford in particular it hurts.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: When I look at the cherry sheets I've got the governor's new cherry sheets for the upcoming year.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And while a little bit of Chapter 70, which is our unrestricted numbers, are going up by measly dollars, we're getting hit with another million dollars net for charter school spending for 424 students.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's an average of about 16 grand a kid that's going out the door for the charter school students, and the average coming in the door with our 70

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: for our over 4,000 students are about a little over $1,000 that we're getting from the Commonwealth.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So there's a huge disparity.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's a huge issue.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Senator Chang-Diaz's bill actually lifts everyone up.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's not really creating animosity between the true publics and the true charters, but it's trying to raise everyone up.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And just as late as Friday,

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: A House representative offered a bill as well, similar to Senator Chang-Diaz's, with some nuances in it.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So there are three bills right now that are tracking in the legislature.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we're going to keep abreast of them all.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I'll notify you as things change to let you know the impacts from each of them.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Senator Diaz's did not have a time number of years for implementation.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The governor had a five-year time that he was going to implement in small doses.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And likewise, the House version has a five-year commitment to it.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So there are a lot of differences between the three bills, and we're hoping that our Metro Mayors Coalition can put together some really good comparisons.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I've tried to sit down and determine what the differences mean, but it's very technical because they're amendments to the current bill, the current law.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So you have to read the current law alongside all the amendments to figure them all out.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So it's very complicated.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Foundation budget, Christine got blessed, is extremely complicated to understand.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mr. Russo, did you want to comment?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: That's a lot of money.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Versus seeing a negative $1 million monetary sheet, which is like, it's shocking.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Shocking.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's shocking to continue to see that downward spiral every year.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So if we could send this to the governor, our state delegation.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: and continue every couple of weeks.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I think we have to re-look at this and then send out blasts and get parents and all of our teachers.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: This impacts teachers, parents, administrators across the board.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we need everybody to be in on this fight collaboratively.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Very good.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Is there a motion on the floor, Mr. Russo, to accept this resolution, seconded by Ms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Van der Kloot, maybe collectively, seconded by all?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Roll call vote, please.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Yes.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: On a vote of six in the affirmative, one absent, motion passes.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mr. Ruggiero.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Great.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I just wanted to elaborate a little bit more on the foundation budget and the education bill, the Promise Act that's been put forth.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And if you looked at the city of Medford over the last several years, when you net out what we get in Chapter 70, which is school funding against our charter school expenses, we're negative.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Every year we've been going down lower and lower.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So the state is contributing less and less to the school system.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And therefore, the property tax burden really is covering

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I think 87% of our school costs are covered through the tax bills.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So it's a huge burden on us.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And then it's very disparate when you compare the urban-suburban.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And it's frustrating, because we really are educating the most vulnerable in the Commonwealth, similar to Boston.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we need that extra help.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So I urge you, as this bill progresses, to really push hard and call your legislators to tell them you're on board.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: At that point in time, we'll do a shout out to parents and educators as well.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: MTA was on board with this.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The Mass Association of School Committees was there as well to support it.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Cross channels and charter schools do not get hindered by this.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They don't get hurt.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So it really lifts everyone up.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So please stay apprised and tune in for further discussions because we're going to need everybody to push for this bill to pass.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's a Senate number, and I can look it up.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: As we know, parents, I believe, is there a parent?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Sara McGiven.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Walk Boston did a safety audit as well just a few weeks ago to look at that area as well.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So it's getting intense scrutiny for sure.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And we've been very successful.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: As you know, the Brooks received this grant.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's in the planning processes.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: MassDOT pretty much takes over the whole process once it's approved.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And they've become the leader of it.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So they are working towards the Brooks School

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: completion as well.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: But this would be a wonderful thing if we were able to get this grant.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So the motion is to go on record officially.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: There is a paper in your packet that is a copy of the letter.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We're going to circulate it after we take the vote and get signatures on it.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: All right.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: There's a motion on the floor for approval by Ms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Roll call vote, please.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Okay, under new business, school committee resolution.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We at Resolve at the Medford School Committee express our sincere condolences to the family of John Welch.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mr. Welch helped manage facilities at the La Conte Brink and was a teacher for 37 years in Somerville.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: He will be missed.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: If I could tell you the amount of people that attended his wake was amazing and the hockey players, the hockey team showed up and they all in their jerseys and

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It was quite a tribute to him.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: He was a wonderful man, and he had an impact on so many.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And he worked at Fenway for many, many years.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So if we could all rise and have a moment of silence on his passing.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And motion to adjourn.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: If you'd all like to sit down.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Good evening clergy, elected officials, chiefs of police, friends and family of police chief-elect Jack Buckley, members of the Metro Police Department, and residents.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: This evening we come together to witness the oath that will be taken shortly by our new police chief, Jack Buckley.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I am proud to be your mayor for this occasion.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: First, I would like to share some historic facts

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The official formation of the police department was on March 21, 1870.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Prior to that, dating back to the 1600s, they were known as peace officers.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: According to Medford on the Mystic, the first full-time police chief was Jophannes H. Whitney, who was appointed on May 1, 1884 in the town of Medford.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The first chief to be named after becoming a city in 1892 was Emery D. Holmes.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: He was paid an annual salary of $1,101.93.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Oddly, in a report presented on February 1, 1892 by Chief Holmes, he said, I would call your attention to the quarters of the police.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I will simply say that the present quarters are entirely inadequate.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The more things change, the more they stay the same.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: There have been 10 police chiefs who have led the women and men of the Medford Police Department since beginning as a city.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: These chiefs strived to make our city safer, build partnerships in the community, and to protect and serve the people of Medford.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Most recently, under the leadership of retired Chief Leo Sacco, we have made great strides in cultivating Medford as a welcoming community.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you, Chief Sacco, for your collaboration, your selflessness, and your leadership.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So tonight, Lieutenant Buckley will join this illustrious group as our 11th permanent police chief.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I'd like to take a moment to speak about Jack's professional career within our department.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: He joined the force in November 1998.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: He was elevated to sergeant in May 2008 and later to permanent lieutenant in September of 2015.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: His employment record is exemplary.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Over the course of my various roles within the city of Medford, I've had the opportunity to work with Jack.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: He is articulate, polite, and well-versed in the subject matter at hand.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Throughout this appointment process, from the first time use of an assessment center to the group interview, Jack demonstrated composure under pressure, presented unique ideas, and a command of 21st century policing.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I was struck by what he thought was an accomplishment of his, that he was proud to be happily married after 20 years and an invested dad to Allison and Sarah.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Kudos, Jack.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: All while serving 20 years on the force.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: This example portrayed his human side and his humble side.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: He also referenced that he is a man he is today due to his upbringing.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The moral compass his parents instilled in him, hard work and being ethical.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: As President John F. Kennedy said, no responsibility of government is more fundamental than the responsibility of maintaining the highest standards of ethical behavior for those who conduct the public business.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And so, with pillar one of the 21st century policing being to build trust and legitimacy, who better to build upon Chief Sacco's legacy than a person who embraces ethics, respect, and trustworthiness?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: As Jack said, law enforcement culture should embrace a guardian rather than a warrior mentality.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: He also acknowledged that the police department does not reflect the proportionality of the makeup of the city of Medford.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: He offered suggestions for augmenting participation in the civil service process for members of our minority community, and tonight I affirm that the mayor's office and chief will commit to offering minority candidates training sessions that will guide individuals through the exam process in order to ensure positive outcomes.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I concur with Chief Holmes stated back in 1892, the current police station is totally inadequate.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: As chief, Jack will be tasked with overseeing the construction of the new police headquarters along with the team that we have assembled.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I am confident that he and all those who have and will work in this new headquarter will be extremely proud of the completed facility.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So in closing, I trust that our new chief will engage in our community through listening sessions.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I trust that our new chief will be a role model for the women and men of the Medford Police Department.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I trust that our new chief will implement the pillars of 21st century policing.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And I trust that our new chief will work hard every day to protect the rights of all.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And I trust that our chief will be a peace officer to the residents of Medford.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I am proud to serve with you, Jack Buckley, in this next chapter of your professional career as Chief of the Medford Police Department.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So at this time, I would like to invite Police Chief-Elect John D. Buckley, his wife Dawn and daughters Allison and Sarah up to the front rail, along with Chief Michael Golding of Weston, formerly of Medford, Massachusetts, who will administer the oath of office.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The meeting of the Medford School Committee will now come to order.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The Secretary will call the roll.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mrs. DiBenedetto?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Present.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Present.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mrs. Van De Koop?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Present.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mayor Burke?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Present.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Seven present, none absent.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: All please rise and salute our flag.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you everyone.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: What a beautiful night to come to this illustrious chamber to hear the beautiful music being played, and at this time we would like to welcome the String Orchestra of Medford High School, led by Mr. Tony Zigny, to play a few more songs for us.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Ms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Wonderful.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mr. Ruggiero.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you so much.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And Happy New Year to all of you as well.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Happy holidays.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I know, my son just bought one of those, full suit.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: For Christmas, yeah.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Next up, we have the approval of the minutes of the December 3rd, 2018 meeting.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mr. Benedetto.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Whereas community participation is critical to a well-functioning school system, and whereas many parents find evenings difficult to arrange child care so that they can attend scheduled meetings, therefore be it resolved that the school committee schedule community participation meetings on two Saturday afternoons every year

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Through participation with parent-teacher groups, child care and entertainment will be made available to parents.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: In addition to school committee activities, other school volunteer groups will post opportunities for further parent engagement.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Also be it resolved that the Medford School Committee expresses sincere condolences to the family of Harvey Howell.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mr. Howell was the father of former EL Director Leslie Trotta and father-in-law of former Director of Technology and Fine Arts and current CCSR Director Richard Trotta.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Also at this time if we could send out our condolences to the families

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: of those that were murdered at the Temple of Worship Synagogue in Pittsburgh.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Our thoughts and prayers are with them and the whole community, including our own Jewish community, that we feel the pain with them.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And also the first responders that ran into the synagogue to help those and also got injured in the line of duty.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So our thoughts and prayers are with them.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: If we could all just rise for a moment of silence, please.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: That looks like it's it.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So moved.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mr. Benedetto.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: While we're into suspension, Mr. Benedetto.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Name and address, please.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mr. Russo.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mr. Jerome?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I don't know if that's a good way to put it.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: to our third graders, everyone gets a dictionary or whatnot.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So it's not really, their fundraiser isn't, like the PTO, everything they do is for this process.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Similar to Friends of Softball, that's strictly for Medford school, it's not for outside entities that can accept the gifts.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mr. Russo.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: This is not on our calendar, so we really shouldn't be delving into this depth or this.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I can't remember back in many years going into the pool area and not seeing Mr. Chaney there, sometimes with his little puppy.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: There is a detailed list, if you need examples of what we're collecting, that's up on the website.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you, ma'am.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I believe November.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: December.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: which became Medford Recreational Hockey.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Am I pronouncing it correctly?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Bertucci.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They performed a heroic act at Hampton Beach this summer in late August, and they basically saved a woman's life there.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we had a wonderful presentation for these two young lads who were very humble.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And they just did an amazing thing.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And I think that they're just a very proud example of our students and how they stand tall and leadership skills that they are learning in the Medford school system.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Yes.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Six in the affirmative one in the negative motion passes the total appropriate fiscal 19 budget 58 6 0 8 6 3 1.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Van der Kloot, on the total superintendent's budget.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So moved, Mr. Russo seconded.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Cripps.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you very much.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I know that there are lots of things that we all would love to have and see.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We really have to put it all together and do what's best for the whole community and there are a lot of resources being spread across it.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And we only have so much of a pie.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So people have to understand that.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's not a tree that produces cash.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We have a limitation on how much revenues we can take in through taxes.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And unfortunately, the cherry sheets, the money we get from the state, it's pretty much been level every year while costs continue to go up.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we're absorbing all the increases, and the state's certainly not helping us with any of that.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So thank you very much.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Report on partnership with Lesley University.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Over the past several months, the City of Medford School Department primarily and Lesley University, high-ranking officials in Lesley University,

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: In addition, Bob Maloney, Mark Grumley, it's been kind of a full court press of meetings with this university.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: What brought them to Medford was a desperate need for some athletic space, predominantly the wood floor.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They would like a wood floor at the high school.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: and also tennis courts.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: That's what brought them to Medford, but once they were in Medford, we realized how much more they can offer to this community.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I've been meeting with several organizations that try to train coaches and school systems in how to deal with trauma.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Leslie's training people to do that type of work.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So they have students that will be looking for internships and co-ops

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: to learn in the field how to be great teachers, how to be great... It's getting late.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: How to be social workers, et cetera.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we think it's a great idea to move forward with Lesley University.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The one contractual item would be for the use of the courts in the cages at Medford High School.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: NCAA requires they be wood floors.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We do not obviously have wood floors right now.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So they would be making an investment in our cages to put in state-of-the-art wood floors, also the scoring mechanism.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: What other things in the cages?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Painting, cleaning it, lighting, plus paying us a fee every year to basically rent the space through this partnership.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Duggar would go through the city side of things.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Right now they have a permit to use Duggar Park.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: for their tennis courts, but they also would like to have a commitment going forward.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we will be working with them on an agreement, and likewise, they will be making improvements to the tennis courts, which our high school team plays on.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: That's their home courts.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we look at it as a win-win opportunity.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We think

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We wanted to speak to the school committee about it to get your thoughts, but we think it's really something very positive for the school system and to have that partnership with Lesley University for our students as well.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Hopefully it'll be a matriculation opportunity and we're just very excited about it.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: If I could just add on the survey, it was used for the search committee purposes to get the search committee off the ground.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Everything that happened in the search committee was executive session, basically, the equivalent of it.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So now that we're out, you should turn them over and we can redact if there's something offensive.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: But otherwise, it's benign.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Ms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Van der Kloot?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And as far as that meeting, it was a special meeting of the school committee.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It was not a committee of the whole,

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's a nomenclature, right?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Same thing.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: But that was posted the way all of the meetings were posted.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So it was public.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It was as public as any other meeting that we hold, just like tonight.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mr. Ruggiero.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Motion passes.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Report on partnership with Lesley University.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Over the past several months, the city of Medford, school department primarily, and Lesley University, high-ranking officials in Lesley University, in addition, Bob Maloney, Mark Grumley, it's been kind of a full-court press of meetings with this university.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: What brought them to Medford was a desperate need for some athletic space, predominantly the wood floor.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They would like a wood floor at the high school.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: and also tennis courts.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: That's what brought them to Medford.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: But once they were in Medford, we realized how much more they can offer to this community.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I've been meeting with several organizations that try to train coaches and school systems in how to deal with trauma.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Leslie's training people to do that type of work.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So they have students that will be looking for internships and co-ops.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: to learn in the field how to be great teachers, how to be great social workers, et cetera.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we think it's a great idea to move forward with Lesley University.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The one contractual item would be for the use of the courts in the cages at Medford High School.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: NCAA requires they be wood floors.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We do not obviously have wood floors right now.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So they would be making an investment in our cages to put in state-of-the-art wood floors, also the scoring mechanism.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: What other things in the cages?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Painting, cleaning it, lighting, plus paying us a fee every year to basically rent the space through this partnership.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Duggar would go through the city side of things.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Right now they have a permit to use Duggar Park.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: for their tennis courts, but they also would like to have a commitment going forward.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we will be working with them on an agreement and likewise, they will be making improvements to the tennis courts, which our high school team plays on.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: That's their home courts.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we look at it as a win-win opportunity.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We think

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We wanted to speak to the school committee about it to get your thoughts but we think it's really something very positive for the school system and to have that partnership with Lesley University for our students as well.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Hopefully it'll be a matriculation opportunity and we're just very excited about it.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The purpose of the committee as a whole is to have our two finalists for superintendent of schools meet with us and to present, do a presentation so that we can better gauge their style and how they interact with us.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So this meeting will come to order at 3 p.m.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The secretary will call the roll.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: By a present to absence, we'll please rise and salute our flag.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And our first finalist with us today is Dr. Maurice Edouard Vincent.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Welcome to Medford.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I know you've spent the better part of today visiting our schools and meeting with central administration as well.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So thank you for the time commitment you've put into this.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And last week we visited Boston.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we spent a lot of time with Dr. Maurice as well as her cohorts.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: and colleagues and we got to know her a little bit better as well.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So thank you for joining us today.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The plan is to do three different scenarios.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The first one has been provided to each of the finalists and they have prepared PowerPoints to present to us today and your discussion points.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And then following that we'll have two short on the fly kind of questions and answers just to finish this off.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Welcome.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Would you like me to read scenario one?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Parents have a choice as to which school they will select.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: One school, the Andrews, attracts more selections

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: than that of the other schools in the blend.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The difference is significant, and the entry grade 6 level, 50 students, is the estimate of disparity.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Please find attached a report that was provided to the school committee on this topic.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: What ideas would you suggest to address this situation?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So if we're currently in the month of May, and we, parents have selected which school they'd like their children to go to next year,

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: This process, I would imagine, would take some time.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So what would be your next steps for the September school year?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mr. Benedetto?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Very good, thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Okay, question number two.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It is 9.30 a.m.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: and your elementary school is in session when it is reported to you by the principal that a water main break has caused a shutdown of all sinks, toilets, water fountains, and kitchen operations.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: There is no clear estimate of how long it will take to clear the water main.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Most parents of your students are at work or at other activities.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: How should you proceed?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: What are your options?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Are there any follow-up questions for Sandy?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Can you follow up on that?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Okay.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Okay, final question.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: You begin the school year 2018-19 with a good budget plan in place.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: In October, you find out that state revenues are falling below projections and the governor plans to make nine seat cuts that will affect your expected funding sources.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The cuts to the special education circuit breaker and homeless transportation will leave you $250,000 short.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Also, there are two unexpected emergency building repairs that will require at least an additional $150,000.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: What will you do to address these issues and maintain a balanced budget?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: By the way, it is only October and you know other financial issues can arise throughout the year.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: What options would you recommend?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We've seen 9C cuts, correct?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Are there any follow-up questions?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you so much.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Those were great responses for impromptu questions.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We really appreciate the time and especially digging deeper into the statistics.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We know staffs don't tell the whole story of the child, so certainly in our trip to Boston, I think we gained a comfort level with how you do look after children in your district and how everything you do really is focused on them.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And, you know, we were really lucky to be able to spend that time with your

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: your partners here.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I guess just one last question.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: If you were selected superintendent, obviously we'll be working on a budget over the next, you know, through the end of the year, and you'd be inheriting that to a degree, so what is your availability to be in our community while you were finishing off Boston?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: As you can tell, we're missing two members.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: One planned, I'm not quite sure on the system.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: In respect of them, we will have a committee of the whole meeting Monday evening.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: What is it, 5?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: 6.15, we scheduled before.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And then we will discuss the two candidates and hopefully we will be reaching a decision that evening.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you so much.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you so much for joining us.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's not coming through.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Welcome back to Medford.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I know you got to spend the day with Central Office and our various principals and teachers the other day, so I hope that that went well.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And we're pretty much at the same format.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I can re-read the question if you'd like.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: There are two middle schools in our city.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Both schools have essentially the same curriculum and staffing levels.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Parents have choice as to which school they will select.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: One school, King Andrews, attracts more selections than the other, the McGlynn.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The difference is significant at the entry grade sixth level.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: 50 students is the estimate.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Please find the task force report that was provided to the school committee on this topic.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: What ideas would you suggest to address the situation?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you very much.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We're going to now move on to two additional questions.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I'll read the first one.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The building emergency.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's 9.30 a.m.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: and your elementary school is in session, but it's reported to you by the principal that a water main break has caused a shutdown of all sinks, toilets, water fountains, and kitchen operations.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: There's no clear estimate how long it will take to repeat a water main.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Most parents of your students are at work or other activities.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: How should you proceed?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: What are your options?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mr. Vendetta?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: You begin the school year of 2018-19 with a good budget plan in place.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: In October, you find out that the state revenues are falling with the low projections and the governor plans to make 90 cuts that will affect your expensive funding sources.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The cost of the special ed circuit breaker and homeless transportation will leave you $250,000 short.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Also, there are two unexpected emergency building repairs that will require at least an additional $150,000.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: What will you do to address these issues and maintain a balanced budget?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And by the way, it is only October and you know other financial issues can arise throughout the year.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: What options would you recommend?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: My follow-up question.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Well, I think we're in a bit of a transition right now.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Clearly, the next few months we need to get through budget negotiations with our teachers union and other unions.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So there's a lot of work that has to take place to just solidify the base.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: But I think one of the largest obstacles, which someone could also look at as

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Something welcoming is the open positions that we will be filling.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So it certainly is an opportunity to create a new way of looking at things and a new energy level, I think, in the community.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So that could be an opportunity, but it is going to be a struggle to get qualified candidates to fill these positions that have been held by people with long tenure here.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I'd say that's one of our obstacles we're facing.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Very good.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Well, thank you so much.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It was a pleasure visiting your community of Lexington and really getting to know the people that you work with.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: They all spoke very highly of you, certainly have high aspirations for you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So you have a lot of support in your current environment.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we thank you for investing in us and we'll be in touch shortly.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I've been asked by the committee just to explain a few procedures.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Recommendations submitted by member Michael Ruggiero that the Medford School Committee go on record in support of the following project and any loan order associated with said project.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Whereas a functioning library is an essential institution to the education of an entire community, and whereas the $12.3 million grant from the Mass Board of Library Commissioners, which has been acquired to finance the construction of a new library, will expire on April 10th, and an additional green library incentive of $430,000,

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Now the FOB has resolved that the School Committee of Medford go on record in support of this project and any law and order associated with said project.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Let us know.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Okay.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And one of the members will keep the minutes because you're doing it off-site and you need two for a quorum.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Ms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mustone is unable to attend.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Motion to revert to the regular order of business by Ms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Kreatz, seconded by Ms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Stone.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: All those in favor?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: All those opposed?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Motion passes.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Recommendation to approve incident report policy.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: This is a motion for approval by Ms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mostone, seconded by Ms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Van der Kloot.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Roll call vote, please.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Policy.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Ms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: DiBenedetto.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It is the report.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I read it at our meeting last week, but I will read it again.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Policy definitions.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Discovery.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Finding any object or observing any situation that applies to the safety and security of the school and or school district which would negatively impact the well-being of students, faculty and staff.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Notification.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Verbal and or written communication to the appropriate authority including but not limited to the police department.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Disposition, reporting of actions taken and conclusions reached that describe and explain the nature of the threat and or behavior identified, as well as any recommendations that emerge from the investigation.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The policy is any individual who discovers an item, including but not limited to weapons, ammunition, explosives, drugs, any contraband items, shall notify the Medford Police Department immediately and inform the principal.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: If the principal cannot be reached, the individual who discovers the item should notify the superintendent of schools.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: This process will be in effect on a 24 hours a day, seven day a week basis.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: As soon as possible, the principal shall prepare a written report surrounding the incident and submit to the superintendent of schools.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The school administration will promptly notify parents of situations that may affect the well-being of students, faculty, and staff.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: These notifications will be done consistent with applicable law, regulations, and policies of the Medford schools.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Additionally, principals are required to immediately notify the office of the superintendent of schools about other incidents, including, but not limited to, accidents, fires, and suspension expulsion of students.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Written reports concerning the incidents must be submitted to the superintendent no later than the next day following the incident.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The principal or his or her designee must also notify the mayor and members of the school committee as soon as possible.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Upon disposition of the investigation, the superintendent, in conjunction with the police department, will provide an appropriate written report to the mayor, school committee, and principal.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: This report shall include the facts surrounding the situation, conclusions reached, as well as any recommendations to be considered.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: This policy will be integrated into all annual reviews, contracts for rentals of our facilities, and school handbooks.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: There's a motion on the floor for approval as seconded.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Ms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Kreatz, is there a question?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: As always, Ms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Van, very thoughtful comments.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And actually today we had a meeting.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Ms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Nelson was present.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Dr. Perrella, as well as our middle school principals, Mr. DeLever and assistant principal, Ms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Liu, was present.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And we discussed that exact item, because it seems that people are getting information that really isn't necessary.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The overhearing of a child saying something, and it being investigated, and it turns out to be simple just talk between two youngsters.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Certainly, a call out to the community isn't necessary.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: School committee will continue to be informed of things that go on, but it certainly, there has to be some decision making that happens.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I think Ms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Nelson, were you going to?

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So there's a threat assessment matrix that has been incorporated into prior incidents.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: What we're going to add on is another column that talks about notification.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So once they get through the boxes and they reach this set, yes, we need to inform the public and the teachers and the whole school system.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: There's a roll call vote on the floor for this policy of incident report policy.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Yes, seven in the affirmative, zero in the negative.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The motion passes.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The items should be clear enough that people can figure out what is going to be the topic.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So at this point in time, Ms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: New business, school committee resolution.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Be it resolved that the Medford School Committee express its sincere condolences to the family of Irene Anestis.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mrs. Anestis was the former secretary for the School Buildings and Grounds Department.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Be it resolved that the Medford School Committee express its sincere condolences to the family of Tilly Fodey.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mrs. Fodey was a long-time Medford resident and Medford High School secretary.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And be it resolved that the Medford School Committee express its sincere condolences to the family of Joe Small.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mr. Small was a retired Medford firefighter and father of Robert Small, former teacher at the vocational school.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: If we could all rise for a moment of silence.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Also under new business,

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Be it resolved that the Medford School Committee review its current policies and practices on school rentals and take actions as deemed necessary to enhance the safety and security of our schools.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: As we realize, I think this is something that's going to need a broader conversation, perhaps in a subcommittee, to determine how we want to move forward.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Over the past two weekends, we have canceled, for the most part, events at our outlying schools, not the high school, but our McGlynn, Andrews, and Brooks school for rentals that have been occurring in the interest of safety.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: And also, we have been putting so many resources into the high school that

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: There was just no way we could cover all four.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we need to make decisions on whether or not we want to reopen these schools, if we want to add on a detail rate to the form, so that anyone that would like to rent the

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: The facilities, there is a cost above and beyond the rental fee that covers coverage, whether it be a detail or security presence.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So we need to figure out those things that we can move forward with our rental program or cease rentals altogether.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So that certainly is a call that the school committee needs to make and assumption that can, from a security standpoint, it could be discussed in executive session as well if we wanted to discuss security measures.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So I don't know if that's... So applications, the deadline was February 28th, so applications are closed from anyone wishing to apply.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Questions have been developed and tomorrow night are actually going to be finalized by the search committee, so certainly the survey should be cut off.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Okay.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: If you could just make a note that... I know, we were talking about this and we shifted gears.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We need to give guidance to community schools on the rental situation.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: So, Ms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Van der Kloot.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: This was actually on the agenda.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It just didn't reprint it.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: No, no.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Thank you, Ms.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Vandermeer.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Mr. Rousseau.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: I would say one case, it's a soccer program at the Brooks School.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: It's a church group at the McGlynn School.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: We're not talking about the high school facility.

[Stephanie Muccini Burke]: Oh, definitely.
